provisions.title: Prohibition Against Violating Safeguards and Privacy Rules
provisions.summary: Respondent must not violate any provision of the GLB Act's Safeguards Rule (16 C.F.R. Part 314) or Privacy Rule (16 C.F.R. Part 313), directly or through any subsidiary, division, website, or other device.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)(1); Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 314; Privacy of Consumer Financial Information Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 313

provisions.title: Third-Party Security Assessment
provisions.summary: Respondent must obtain biennial independent third-party assessments of its information security program, certifying that safeguards comply with the Safeguards Rule and adequately protect nonpublic personal information.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)(1); Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 314; Privacy of Consumer Financial Information Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 313

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgment and Delivery
provisions.summary: Respondent must deliver a copy of this order to all current and future principals, officers, directors, managers, and supervisory employees within 30 days of service (current) or assumption of responsibilities (future).
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)(1); Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 314; Privacy of Consumer Financial Information Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 313

provisions.title: Notification of Corporate Changes
provisions.summary: Respondent must notify the FTC at least 30 days prior to any corporate change that may affect compliance obligations, including dissolution, merger, bankruptcy, or name/address change.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)(1); Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 314; Privacy of Consumer Financial Information Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 313

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Respondent must file a written compliance report with the FTC within 180 days after service of the order, and at other times as required, detailing how it has complied; the initial report must include the first biennial Assessment.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)(1); Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 314; Privacy of Consumer Financial Information Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 313

provisions.title: Order Duration and Termination
provisions.summary: The order terminates on January 3, 2025, or 20 years from the most recent date the FTC files a complaint alleging a violation of the order in federal court, whichever is later, subject to specified exceptions.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)(1); Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 314; Privacy of Consumer Financial Information Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 313

provisions.title: Civil Penalty
provisions.summary: Defendant is ordered to pay a $35,000 civil penalty pursuant to Section 621(a) of the FCRA, with funds held in escrow by former counsel to be transferred to the Commission within 5 days of entry of the Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 628 of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. § 1681w; and the Disposal Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 682.1 et seq.

provisions.title: Prohibited Business Activities
provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently restrained from misrepresenting the privacy or security of personal information and from violating Section 628 of the FCRA or the Disposal Rule by failing to properly dispose of consumer information.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 628 of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. § 1681w; and the Disposal Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 682.1 et seq.

provisions.title: Required Information Security Program
provisions.summary: Defendant must establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive written information security program for any business he controls that collects, maintains, or stores personal information from consumers, including specific administrative, technical, and physical safeguards.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 628 of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. § 1681w; and the Disposal Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 682.1 et seq.

provisions.title: Assessment Requirements
provisions.summary: Defendant must obtain initial and annual third-party assessments of his information security program for 10 years, with each assessment certifying the sufficiency of safeguards, prepared by a qualified professional and submitted to or retained for the FTC.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 628 of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. § 1681w; and the Disposal Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 682.1 et seq.

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: Defendant must cooperate with FTC monitoring efforts, including submitting written reports, producing documents, appearing for deposition, and providing entry to business locations within 10 days of written notice; the Commission may also conduct undercover investigations and discovery.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 628 of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. § 1681w; and the Disposal Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 682.1 et seq.

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting by Defendant
provisions.summary: For five years, Defendant must notify the FTC of changes in residence, employment, business structure, and name; file sworn compliance reports every 180 days and annually; and notify the FTC of any bankruptcy filing within 15 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 628 of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. § 1681w; and the Disposal Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 682.1 et seq.

provisions.title: Record Keeping
provisions.summary: Defendant must create and retain specified records for eight years, including documents contradicting compliance, consumer complaints, law enforcement communications, and all compliance records; assessment-related materials must be retained for three years after each assessment.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 628 of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. § 1681w; and the Disposal Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 682.1 et seq.

provisions.title: Distribution of Order by Defendant
provisions.summary: For three years from entry, Defendant must deliver copies of this Order to principals, officers, managers, and supervisory employees of any business entity he controls that handles personal information, and to principals and managers of businesses where he oversees privacy policies, and must obtain signed receipts within 30 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 628 of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. § 1681w; and the Disposal Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 682.1 et seq.

provisions.title: Acknowledgment of Receipt of Order by Defendant
provisions.summary: Defendant must personally submit a sworn statement to the Commission acknowledging receipt of this Order within five business days of receipt.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 628 of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. § 1681w; and the Disposal Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 682.1 et seq.

provisions.title: Retention of Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction of this matter for purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of the Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 628 of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. § 1681w; and the Disposal Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 682.1 et seq.

provisions.title: Prohibited Misleading Representations
provisions.summary: Respondent and all persons acting in concert with it must not make any misrepresentation, express or implied, about any feature of covered software in connection with its advertising, promotion, sale, or distribution.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Mandated Software Security Program
provisions.summary: Respondent must establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive software security program — documented in writing — containing administrative, technical, and physical safeguards addressing software security risks and protecting the security and integrity of covered information.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Software Security Assessments by a Third Party
provisions.summary: Respondent must obtain initial and biennial third-party assessments of its software security program from a qualified independent professional, covering defined reporting periods, with specific content requirements and submission deadlines to the Commission.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Acknowledgments of the Order
provisions.summary: Respondent must submit a sworn acknowledgment of receipt of this Order within 10 days, and for 5 years must deliver a copy of the Order to all principals, officers, directors, and employees or agents with relevant managerial responsibilities, as well as to any successor business entities.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Report and Notices
provisions.summary: Respondent must submit a sworn annual compliance report one year after issuance, provide sworn notices within 14 days of changes in contact information or corporate structure, notify the Commission within 14 days of any bankruptcy filing, and route all submissions per specified instructions.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondent must create specified records for 20 years after Order issuance and retain each for at least 5 years (unless otherwise specified), including accounting records, personnel records, consumer complaints, representations subject to the Order, assessment materials, and all records necessary to demonstrate full compliance.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The Commission is authorized to monitor Respondent's compliance by requiring additional reports and records within 10 days of a written request, communicating directly with Respondent, interviewing affiliated individuals (with counsel present), and using all other lawful means including undercover methods.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Order Effective Dates
provisions.summary: This Order is effective upon publication on the FTC's website and will terminate on December 20, 2037, or 20 years from the most recent date a complaint alleging any violation of this Order is filed in federal court, whichever is later, subject to specified exceptions.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 1681-1681x; Privacy of Consumer Financial Information (Regulation P), 12 C.F.R. provisions.title: Retention of Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction over this matter for purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of the Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 1681-1681x; Privacy of Consumer Financial Information (Regulation P), 12 C.F.R. provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations
provisions.summary: Respondent must not misrepresent, expressly or by implication, the extent to which it collects, maintains, uses, or protects the privacy and security of any Covered Information.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Data Retention and Deletion
provisions.summary: Within 60 days, Respondent must document and follow a Covered Information retention schedule and provide consumers a Clear and Conspicuous link to request data access or deletion.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Multi-Factor Authentication for Users
provisions.summary: Within six months, Respondent must offer multi-factor authentication to consumer users and must not use MFA-collected information for any other purpose.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Notice to Individuals Affected by Identified Breaches
provisions.summary: Within 60 days, Respondent must email the prescribed breach notice (Attachment A) to each individual whose sensitive information was exposed in an Identified Breach and not yet notified.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Mandated Information Security Program
provisions.summary: Within 90 days, Respondent must establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive information security program covering documentation, risk assessments, safeguards, employee training, access controls, MFA, encryption, vulnerability management, and service provider oversight.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Information Security Assessments By A Third Party
provisions.summary: Respondent must obtain initial and biennial independent third-party assessments of its Information Security Program, submit the initial assessment to the FTC within 10 days of completion, and retain subsequent assessments for FTC review on request.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Cooperation With Third-Party Information Security Assessor
provisions.summary: Respondent must fully cooperate with third-party Assessors by providing all relevant information, network and IT asset visibility, and disclosing all material facts without misrepresentation.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Annual Certifications
provisions.summary: Beginning one year after Order issuance and annually thereafter, a senior corporate manager or officer must certify to the FTC that Respondent has established and maintained Order requirements and is unaware of uncorrected material noncompliance.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Covered Incident Reports
provisions.summary: Within ten days of notifying any U.S. government entity of a Covered Incident, Respondent must submit a detailed report to the FTC including dates, descriptions, affected consumer counts, remediation actions, and copies of consumer notices.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgements
provisions.summary: Respondent must submit its own sworn acknowledgment of the Order within 10 days, deliver copies to relevant personnel, and obtain signed acknowledgments from each recipient within 30 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Respondent must file an initial sworn compliance report one year after issuance, provide sworn notices of material changes within 14 days for 12 years, and notify the FTC of any bankruptcy filing within 14 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondent must create and retain for 5 years (over a 12-year creation period) records including accounting data, personnel records, consumer complaints, all compliance documentation, and copies of privacy/security-related marketing materials.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The FTC may monitor Respondent's compliance by requesting additional reports, conducting depositions and document inspections, communicating directly with Respondent, interviewing affiliated personnel, and using other lawful means including undercover methods.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Order Effective Dates and Duration
provisions.summary: The Order is effective upon publication on ftc.gov and terminates 20 years from issuance or 20 years from the most recent federal court complaint alleging a violation, whichever is later, subject to specified exceptions.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations
provisions.summary: Corporate Respondent must not misrepresent how it collects, uses, discloses, or protects Covered Information, or misrepresent the extent of any Covered Incident or unauthorized disclosure.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)(1)

provisions.title: Mandated Deletion and Data Minimization
provisions.summary: Corporate Respondent must delete all Covered Information not being used for customer services within 60 days, report the deletion to the Commission, and refrain from collecting or maintaining unnecessary Covered Information going forward.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)(1)

provisions.title: Data Retention Limits
provisions.summary: Corporate Respondent must document, adhere to, and publicly post a retention schedule for Covered Information within 60 days, report it to the Commission, and update the schedule before collecting any new types of consumer information.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)(1)

provisions.title: Mandated Information Security Program for Covered Businesses
provisions.summary: Corporate Respondent and all Covered Businesses must establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive information security program within 60 days, meeting detailed minimum requirements including written documentation, risk assessments, safeguards, training, access controls, monitoring, and vendor management.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)(1)

provisions.title: Third Party Information Security Assessments for Covered Businesses
provisions.summary: Corporate Respondent must obtain initial and biennial independent third-party assessments of its Information Security Program, using a qualified assessor approved by the FTC, covering defined reporting periods for 20 years, with completed assessments submitted to the Commission.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)(1)

provisions.title: Cooperation with Third-Party Information Security Assessor
provisions.summary: Respondents must fully cooperate with the third-party assessor by providing all relevant information, granting network and IT asset visibility, and disclosing all material facts without misrepresentation.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)(1)

provisions.title: Mandated Information Security Program for Certain Businesses of the Individual Respondent
provisions.summary: For 10 years after issuance, Individual Respondent must ensure that any Relevant Business for which he is a majority owner or senior officer with information security responsibility establishes and maintains a comprehensive information security program meeting detailed minimum requirements within 180 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)(1)

provisions.title: Annual Certification
provisions.summary: Corporate Respondent must submit an annual certification to the Commission from its CEO (or designated senior officer) confirming compliance with the Order, absence of uncorrected material noncompliance, and describing all verified Covered Incidents during the certified period.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)(1)

provisions.title: Covered Incident Reports
provisions.summary: Within 10 days of notifying any U.S. government entity of a Covered Incident, each Covered Business must submit a detailed report to the Commission including the date, facts, types and number of consumers affected, remediation steps, and copies of consumer notices.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)(1)

provisions.title: Acknowledgments of the Order
provisions.summary: Each Respondent must acknowledge receipt of the Order within 10 days, deliver copies of the Order to all relevant principals, officers, and employees within 10 days (and to future personnel before they assume responsibilities), and obtain signed acknowledgments from each recipient within 30 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)(1)

provisions.title: Compliance Report and Notices
provisions.summary: Each Respondent must submit an initial compliance report one year after issuance, provide timely notices of any material changes (within 14 days), and notify the Commission of any bankruptcy filings within 14 days, with all submissions made under penalty of perjury.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)(1)

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondents must create records for 20 years and retain them for 5 years (unless otherwise specified), covering accounting records, personnel records, consumer complaints, advertising materials, privacy representations, Assessment materials, law enforcement communications, noncompliance records, and all records necessary to demonstrate full compliance.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)(1)

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The Commission is authorized to monitor Respondents' compliance by requesting additional reports and records within 10 days, communicating directly with and interviewing affiliated persons, and using any other lawful means including undercover methods.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)(1)

provisions.title: Order Effective Dates and Duration
provisions.summary: This Order is effective upon publication on the FTC's website and terminates 20 years from its issuance date, or 20 years from the most recent date the Commission files a complaint alleging a violation, whichever is later, subject to specified exceptions.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)(1)

provisions.title: Prohibition against Misrepresentations about Privacy and Security
provisions.summary: Respondent must not misrepresent, expressly or by implication, its privacy and security measures, program memberships, user privacy choices, deletion/retention practices, or the extent to which it protects Personal Information.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45

provisions.title: Mandated Information Security Program
provisions.summary: Respondent must establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive information security program within 60 days of order issuance, meeting a detailed set of minimum requirements covering documentation, risk assessment, safeguards, testing, and vendor management.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45

provisions.title: Independent Program Assessments by a Third Party
provisions.summary: Respondent must obtain initial and biennial third-party assessments of its Information Security Program, using qualified independent assessors approved by the FTC, covering specified reporting periods and content requirements, and submit results to the Commission.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45

provisions.title: Annual Certification
provisions.summary: Respondent must annually provide the FTC with a sworn certification from a senior corporate manager or officer confirming compliance with the Order, disclosing any material noncompliance, and describing all Covered Incidents during the period.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45

provisions.title: Covered Incident Reports
provisions.summary: Respondent must submit a report to the FTC within 30 days of discovering a Covered Incident, including details about the incident's date, causes, affected information types, number of consumers affected, remediation steps, and copies of consumer notices.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45

provisions.title: Monetary Relief
provisions.summary: Respondent must pay $500,000 to the Commission within 8 days of the effective date of the Order via electronic fund transfer.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45

provisions.title: Additional Monetary Provisions
provisions.summary: Respondent relinquishes all rights to transferred assets, the Complaint facts are deemed true in any subsequent enforcement litigation, paid funds may be used for consumer redress or related relief, and interest and penalties accrue on default.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45

provisions.title: Customer Information
provisions.summary: Respondent must provide sufficient customer information to enable the Commission to administer consumer redress to shopkeepers who did not receive payable commissions, and must respond to written information requests within 14 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45

provisions.title: Acknowledgments of the Order

provisions.title: Compliance Reports and Notices

provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45

provisions.title: Recordkeeping

provisions.title: Monetary Judgment

provisions.title: Compliance Reports and Notices

provisions.title: Recordkeeping

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring

provisions.title: Third Party Information Security Assessments for Covered Businesses
provisions.summary: Respondents must obtain initial and biennial third-party assessments of their Information Security Program for 20 years.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Section 5(a) and 5(n) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a), (n)

provisions.title: Cooperation with Third-Party Information Security Assessor
provisions.summary: Respondents must provide all relevant information to the third-party Assessor and not misrepresent any material facts.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Section 5(a) and 5(n) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a), (n)

provisions.title: Annual Certification
provisions.summary: Respondents must provide annual certifications from the CEO or senior officer confirming compliance with the Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Section 5(a) and 5(n) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a), (n)

provisions.title: Covered Incident Reports
provisions.summary: Respondents must report to the FTC any Covered Incidents affecting 500 or more consumers within 10 days of notifying government entities.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Section 5(a) and 5(n) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a), (n)

provisions.title: Acknowledgments of the Order
provisions.summary: Respondents must obtain signed acknowledgments of the Order from all relevant personnel and entities for 20 years.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Section 5(a) and 5(n) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a), (n)

provisions.title: Compliance Reports and Notices
provisions.summary: Respondents must submit annual compliance reports and timely notices of any structural changes or bankruptcy proceedings.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Section 5(a) and 5(n) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a), (n)

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondents must create and retain records for 20 years documenting compliance with all provisions of the Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Section 5(a) and 5(n) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a), (n)

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The FTC has authority to monitor compliance through requests for reports, depositions, document production, and interviews.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Section 5(a) and 5(n) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a), (n)

provisions.title: Modification of Original Decision and Order
provisions.summary: This Order supersedes the 2010 Decision and Order previously issued against Rite Aid.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Section 5(a) and 5(n) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a), (n)

provisions.title: Order Effective Dates
provisions.summary: The Order is effective upon publication on ftc.gov and terminates 20 years from issuance or from the most recent complaint filing, whichever is later.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Section 5(a) and 5(n) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a), (n)

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations
provisions.summary: Respondents must not misrepresent in any manner the extent to which they maintain and protect the privacy, security, confidentiality, or integrity of Covered Information.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Mandated Information Security Program for Covered Businesses
provisions.summary: Within 90 days of the effective date, Respondents must establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive Information Security Program protecting the security, confidentiality, and integrity of Covered Information, including extensive safeguards, vendor management, and ongoing risk assessments.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Third Party Information Security Assessments for Covered Businesses
provisions.summary: Respondents must obtain initial and biennial independent third-party assessments of their Information Security Program, covering the first 180 days after the Program is established and every two years thereafter for 20 years.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Cooperation with Third-Party Information Security Assessor
provisions.summary: Respondents must fully cooperate with the Assessor by providing all relevant information, disclosing network and IT asset details, and not misrepresenting any material facts to the Assessor.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Annual Certification
provisions.summary: One year after issuance, and each year thereafter, Respondents must provide the FTC with a sworn certification from a senior executive confirming compliance with the Order, absence of uncorrected/undisclosed material noncompliance, and a description of all qualifying Covered Incidents during the certified period.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Covered Incident Reports
provisions.summary: Within 10 days of notifying any U.S. government entity of a Covered Incident affecting 500 or more consumers, Respondents must submit a detailed report to the FTC.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Acknowledgments of the Order
provisions.summary: Respondents must submit acknowledgment of receipt of the Order within 10 days, deliver copies to all principals, officers, directors, subsidiaries, and relevant employees, and obtain signed acknowledgments within 30 days of delivery.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Compliance Reports and Notices
provisions.summary: Respondents must submit annual compliance reports, compliance notices within 14 days of changes in contact information or corporate structure, and bankruptcy filing notices within 14 days of filing.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondents must create certain records for 20 years after issuance and retain each for five years, including accounting records, personnel records, consumer complaints, compliance records, System Assessment materials, security representations, Assessor materials, law enforcement subpoenas, and noncompliance records.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The FTC is authorized to monitor Respondents' compliance through requests for reports and records, depositions, discovery, direct communications, interviews, and undercover methods, with Respondents obligated to respond within 14 days of written requests.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Modification of Original Decision and Order
provisions.summary: This Decision and Order supersedes and replaces the Commission's 2010 Decision and Order in In re Rite Aid Corporation, C-4308.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Order Effective Dates and Duration
provisions.summary: The Order is effective upon publication on the FTC's website and terminates 20 years from issuance or 20 years from the most recent federal court complaint alleging a violation, whichever is later, with specified exceptions for individual provisions, non-defendant respondents, and dismissed complaints.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Violating GLB Safeguards and Privacy Rules
provisions.summary: Respondents must not violate any provision of the GLB Act's Safeguards Rule (16 C.F.R. Part 314) or Privacy Rule (16 C.F.R. Part 313), directly or through any corporate entity or device.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)(1), and Title V of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, 15 U.S.C. § 6801 et seq.

provisions.title: Third-Party Security Assessment
provisions.summary: Respondents must obtain biennial independent third-party security assessments certifying their information security program, and provide the first assessment and related materials to the FTC within 10 days of preparation.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)(1), and Title V of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, 15 U.S.C. § 6801 et seq.

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgment and Delivery
provisions.summary: Respondents must deliver a copy of this order to all current and future principals, officers, directors, managers, employees, agents, and representatives with relevant responsibilities — current personnel within 30 days of service, future personnel within 30 days of assuming their role.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)(1), and Title V of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, 15 U.S.C. § 6801 et seq.

provisions.title: Employment Change Notification — John D. Eubank
provisions.summary: Respondent John D. Eubank must notify the FTC for 10 years of any discontinuance of current business or employment, or any affiliation with new business or employment, including new address, phone number, and description of duties.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)(1), and Title V of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, 15 U.S.C. § 6801 et seq.

provisions.title: Corporate Change Notification
provisions.summary: Respondents must notify the FTC at least 30 days before any corporate change (dissolution, merger, sale, name change, bankruptcy filing, etc.) that may affect compliance obligations under this order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)(1), and Title V of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, 15 U.S.C. § 6801 et seq.

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Respondents must file a written compliance report with the FTC within 180 days of service of the order, and at such other times as the FTC may require, including a copy of the initial Assessment from Part II.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)(1), and Title V of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, 15 U.S.C. § 6801 et seq.

provisions.title: Order Duration and Termination
provisions.summary: This order terminates on April 12, 2025, or 20 years from the most recent date the FTC or United States files a federal court complaint alleging a violation of the order, whichever is later, subject to specified exceptions.

provisions.title: Mandated Information Security Program
provisions.summary: Each Covered Business must establish and maintain a comprehensive information security program with documented safeguards, designated coordinators, risk assessments, testing, service provider oversight, and regular evaluation.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d)

provisions.summary: Defendants must obtain an initial and biennial third-party assessments of the information security program by a qualified assessor (CISSP, CISA, or GIAC-certified), covering the first 180 days and each 2-year period thereafter for ten years, with results submitted to the FTC.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d)

provisions.summary: Defendants must not misrepresent, expressly or by implication, any fact material to the Assessor's determination of compliance, effectiveness of the security program, or identification of gaps or weaknesses.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d)

provisions.summary: Defendants must provide annual certifications to the FTC for ten years from a senior corporate manager or officer of each Covered Business confirming compliance with the Order, noting any material noncompliance, and describing any Covered Incidents.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d)

provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b), and Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.summary: Within 180 days, Defendant must establish a comprehensive privacy and data security program covering documentation, risk assessments, safeguards, training, access controls, monitoring, testing, service provider oversight, and program evaluation, and maintain it for 20 years.

provisions.summary: Defendant must obtain initial and biennial third-party assessments of its privacy and data security program from qualified, independent assessors, covering the first year and each two-year period thereafter for 20 years, with assessments completed within 60 days after each reporting period ends.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b), and Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Cooperation with Third-Party Assessor(s)
provisions.summary: Defendant must fully cooperate with Assessors by providing all relevant information, granting visibility into networks and IT assets, and disclosing all material facts without misrepresentation.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b), and Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.summary: Starting one year after entry and annually for 20 years, the Ring Principal Executive Officer must certify to the Commission that Defendant has established and maintained the Order's requirements and is unaware of any undisclosed material noncompliance.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b), and Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Covered Incident Reports
provisions.summary: For 20 years, Defendant must report Covered Incidents to the Commission within 10 days of notifying any U.S. government entity or determining no notice is needed, including details about the incident, affected consumers, remediation steps, and copies of consumer notices.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b), and Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Notices to Customers
provisions.summary: Defendant must identify all consumers with Ring accounts before February 1, 2018, and send each a notice (per Attachment A) within 180 days of Order entry, and notify any newly identified eligible customers within 30 days of their identification.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b), and Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Monetary Judgment
provisions.summary: Judgment of $5,800,000 is entered against Defendant, payable to the Commission within 7 days of Order entry via electronic fund transfer.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b), and Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Additional Monetary Provisions
provisions.summary: Defendant relinquishes all rights to transferred assets, the Complaint's facts may be taken as true in future enforcement proceedings, Defendant must submit its Taxpayer Identification Number, and all money paid may be used for equitable relief or deposited to the U.S. Treasury.

provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule (Safeguards Rule), 16 C.F.R. Part 314, issued pursuant to Sections 501-504 of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6801-6804

provisions.title: Cooperation with Third Party Information Security Assessor
provisions.summary: Defendant must not withhold material facts from or misrepresent any material fact to the Assessor, and must provide the Assessor full access to its network, IT assets, and all relevant information and materials.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule (Safeguards Rule), 16 C.F.R. Part 314, issued pursuant to Sections 501-504 of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6801-6804

provisions.title: Annual Certification
provisions.summary: Defendant must provide annual certifications to the Commission for twenty years from a board-level or senior officer attesting to compliance with the Order, absence of material noncompliance, cooperation with the Assessor, and describing any Covered Incidents.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule (Safeguards Rule), 16 C.F.R. Part 314, issued pursuant to Sections 501-504 of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6801-6804

provisions.title: Covered Incident Reports
provisions.summary: For twenty years, Defendant must report Covered Incidents to the Commission no later than ten days after first notifying any government entity, with detailed information about the incident, and provide quarterly summaries to its board.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule (Safeguards Rule), 16 C.F.R. Part 314, issued pursuant to Sections 501-504 of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6801-6804

provisions.title: Monetary Judgment and Additional Monetary Obligations
provisions.summary: A monetary judgment of $425,000,000 is entered against Defendant, with additional financial obligations triggered if more than seven million Affected Consumers enroll in the Product, calculated using specified formulas during both the Initial and Extended Claims Periods.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule (Safeguards Rule), 16 C.F.R. Part 314, issued pursuant to Sections 501-504 of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6801-6804

provisions.title: Consumer Restitution and Redress Through Multi-District Litigation
provisions.summary: Consumer relief may be conducted through the Multi-District Litigation Settlement rather than directly by the Commission, with Defendant required to deposit $300,000,000 into the Consumer Fund in specified tranches and up to an additional $125,000,000 if needed.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule (Safeguards Rule), 16 C.F.R. Part 314, issued pursuant to Sections 501-504 of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6801-6804

provisions.title: Consumer Fund for Multi-District Litigation
provisions.summary: At least $300,000,000 (plus any additional deposits) in the Consumer Fund must be used exclusively to provide restitution and redress to Affected Consumers through specified categories of relief including credit monitoring, out-of-pocket loss reimbursement, identity restoration services, and administrative costs.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule (Safeguards Rule), 16 C.F.R. Part 314, issued pursuant to Sections 501-504 of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6801-6804

provisions.title: Notice and Claims in Multi-District Litigation
provisions.summary: If Defendant deposits money into the Consumer Fund, it must supply information to the Notice Provider and Settlement Administrator, notify the Commission of any modifications, provide weekly and annual reports to the Commission, and cooperate fully in claims administration.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule (Safeguards Rule), 16 C.F.R. Part 314, issued pursuant to Sections 501-504 of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6801-6804

provisions.title: Reversion of Consumer Relief to Administration by Commission
provisions.summary: The Commission may end its forbearance and collect the monetary judgment directly upon written notice of specified Termination Events, at which point Defendant must make direct payments to the Commission within twenty-one days and continue to cooperate in consumer relief administration.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule (Safeguards Rule), 16 C.F.R. Part 314, issued pursuant to Sections 501-504 of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6801-6804

provisions.title: Additional Monetary Provisions
provisions.summary: Defendant relinquishes all rights to assets transferred under this Order, facts in the Complaint are deemed true for enforcement proceedings, and all money paid to the Commission will be used for consumer relief consistent with Section IX.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule (Safeguards Rule), 16 C.F.R. Part 314, issued pursuant to Sections 501-504 of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6801-6804

provisions.title: Single-Bureau Monitoring and Identity Theft Protection
provisions.summary: Defendant must offer single-bureau credit monitoring to Affected Consumers upon expiration of the Product (up to ten years aggregate), additional years for minors (up to eighteen years aggregate), free security freezes for ten years, and six free Personal Consumer Reports per year for seven years.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule (Safeguards Rule), 16 C.F.R. Part 314, issued pursuant to Sections 501-504 of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6801-6804

provisions.title: Prohibition on Advertising or Marketing to Consumers Who Use Identity Theft Protection Services
provisions.summary: Defendant must not use information provided by Affected Consumers through the Order's identity theft protection services to sell, upsell, cross-sell, or market its products or services unless it makes a Clear and Conspicuous disclosure and obtains affirmative express consent.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule (Safeguards Rule), 16 C.F.R. Part 314, issued pursuant to Sections 501-504 of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6801-6804

provisions.title: Additional Notice
provisions.summary: Defendant must provide specific notices to Affected Consumers and the general public, including website hyperlinks, press releases, and social media posts directing consumers to the Settlement Website, within specified timeframes.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule (Safeguards Rule), 16 C.F.R. Part 314, issued pursuant to Sections 501-504 of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6801-6804

provisions.title: Rule Violations
provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently restrained and enjoined from violating any provision of the Standards for Safeguarding Consumer Information Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 314.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule (Safeguards Rule), 16 C.F.R. Part 314, issued pursuant to Sections 501-504 of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6801-6804

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgments
provisions.summary: Defendant must submit a sworn acknowledgment of receipt of this Order within seven days, deliver copies of the Order to all principals, officers, directors, managerial employees, and affected business entities for ten years, and obtain signed acknowledgments within 30 days of delivery.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule (Safeguards Rule), 16 C.F.R. Part 314, issued pursuant to Sections 501-504 of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6801-6804

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Defendant must submit an annual compliance report one year after entry of the Order, notify the Commission within 14 days of any changes to designated contacts or entity structure for 20 years, and notify the Commission within 14 days of any bankruptcy filing.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule (Safeguards Rule), 16 C.F.R. Part 314, issued pursuant to Sections 501-504 of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6801-6804

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Defendant must create certain records for 20 years after entry of the Order and retain each such record for 5 years, including accounting records, personnel records, consumer complaints, information security assessments, representations about data security, and all materials related to Assessments.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule (Safeguards Rule), 16 C.F.R. Part 314, issued pursuant to Sections 501-504 of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6801-6804

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The Commission has broad authority to monitor Defendant's compliance, including obtaining additional compliance reports, conducting depositions and discovery, communicating directly with Defendant, interviewing employees, and using undercover means.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule (Safeguards Rule), 16 C.F.R. Part 314, issued pursuant to Sections 501-504 of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6801-6804

provisions.title: Severability
provisions.summary: If any clause, provision, or section of the Order is held illegal, invalid, or unenforceable, the remaining provisions remain in full force and effect.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule (Safeguards Rule), 16 C.F.R. Part 314, issued pursuant to Sections 501-504 of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6801-6804

provisions.title: Retention of Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction of this matter for purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of this Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule (Safeguards Rule), 16 C.F.R. Part 314, issued pursuant to Sections 501-504 of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6801-6804

provisions.summary: Respondent must create specified records for 20 years after the Order's issuance date and retain each for 5 years (unless otherwise specified), including accounting records, personnel records, consumer complaints, compliance records, privacy representations, assessment materials, bug bounty reports, law enforcement communications, and records contradicting compliance.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The FTC may monitor Respondent's compliance by requiring additional reports and records within 10 days of a written request, communicating directly with and interviewing Respondent's personnel, and using all other lawful means including undercover approaches.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Order Effective Dates
provisions.summary: The Order is effective upon publication on the FTC's website and terminates on October 25, 2038, or 20 years from the most recent date the FTC files a complaint alleging any violation of the Order in federal court, whichever is later, subject to specified exceptions.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Permanent Injunction — Continuation
provisions.summary: The original Permanent Injunction remains in full force and effect, except that Sections VI through IX are replaced by Sections V through VIII of this Amended Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Monetary Judgment and Consumer Redress
provisions.summary: A judgment of $100,000,000 is entered against LifeLock; LifeLock must deposit the full amount into the Court's Registry within five business days and satisfy all related obligations governing disbursement, crediting, and remittance to the Commission.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Customer Information
provisions.summary: LifeLock must provide customer information requested by the Commission to facilitate consumer redress, including responding to written requests within 10 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Entry of Order
provisions.summary: The court finds no just reason for delay and directs the clerk to enter the Order immediately.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: For five years, LifeLock must notify the Commission of corporate changes at least 30 days in advance, file annual sworn compliance reports, and notify the Commission of any bankruptcy filings within 15 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The Commission is authorized to monitor LifeLock's compliance through written reports, document production, depositions, site inspections, undercover investigations, and employee interviews, using all lawful means including civil discovery.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Record Keeping Provisions
provisions.summary: LifeLock must create and retain specified categories of records for defined periods: 13 years from the Permanent Injunction for business and compliance records, 3 years for biennial assessment materials, and 5 years from this Order for consumer redress payment records.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Distribution of Order
provisions.summary: For five years, LifeLock must deliver copies of the Permanent Injunction and this Order to principals, officers, relevant employees, agents, and successor entities, and obtain signed acknowledgments of receipt within 30 days of delivery.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Acknowledgement of Receipt of This Order
provisions.summary: LifeLock must submit a sworn statement to the Commission acknowledging receipt of this Order within five business days of receiving it.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Retention of Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction over this matter for all purposes.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Privacy and Security
provisions.summary: Respondents must not misrepresent in any manner their collection, maintenance, use, deletion, or disclosure of Personal Information, or the extent to which they protect the privacy, security, availability, confidentiality, or integrity of Personal Information.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Mandated Information Security Program
provisions.summary: Respondents must establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive information security program within 180 days of the effective date, encompassing risk assessments, safeguards, training, incident response, access controls, encryption, vulnerability management, vendor oversight, and franchisee requirements.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Information Security Assessments by a Third Party
provisions.summary: Respondents must obtain initial and biennial third-party assessments of their Information Security Program from a qualified, independent assessor, covering the first 365 days and each 2-year period thereafter for 20 years, and submit assessments to the FTC.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Cooperation with Third-Party Information Security Assessor
provisions.summary: Respondents must fully cooperate with the Third-Party Assessor by providing all relevant information, disclosing all material facts, and not misrepresenting any fact material to the assessment.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Annual Certification
provisions.summary: Respondents must provide an annual CEO certification to the FTC confirming compliance with the Order and disclosing any uncorrected material noncompliance.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Covered Incident Reports
provisions.summary: Within 10 days of notifying any U.S. government entity of a Covered Incident, Respondents must submit a detailed report to the FTC including incident dates, causes, types of information affected, number of consumers impacted, remediation steps taken, and copies of notices sent.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Loyalty Rewards Program Accounts Review
provisions.summary: Respondents must provide U.S. consumers a clear and conspicuous method to request review of their Loyalty Rewards Program account for unauthorized activity within the preceding 12 months, and restore points lost to unauthorized third-party activity.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Acknowledgments of the Order
provisions.summary: Respondents must submit a sworn acknowledgment of receipt of the Order to the FTC within 10 days, deliver copies to all relevant officers, directors, employees, and agents, and obtain signed acknowledgments within 30 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Reports and Notices
provisions.summary: Respondents must submit a sworn compliance report one year after issuance, provide compliance notices within 14 days of any designated contact or structural changes, notify the Commission of any bankruptcy filings within 14 days, and submit all filings via email or overnight courier.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondents must create and retain specified records for 20 years after issuance (retaining each record for 5 years), including accounting records, personnel records, consumer complaints, privacy representations, third-party assessment materials, law enforcement communications, and all compliance records.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The FTC has the authority to monitor Respondents' compliance by requesting additional reports and records within 10 days, communicating directly with and interviewing Respondents' affiliates, and using all other lawful means including undercover methods.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Order Effective Dates
provisions.summary: The Order is effective upon publication on the FTC's website and terminates 20 years from its issuance date, or 20 years from the most recent federal court complaint alleging a violation, whichever is later, subject to specified exceptions.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations
provisions.summary: Respondents must not misrepresent in any manner the extent to which they maintain and protect the privacy, security, confidentiality, or integrity of Covered Information, including misrepresentations about security measures, privacy choices, data collection/use/deletion practices, or third-party access.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Mandated Information Security Program for Covered Businesses
provisions.summary: Within 90 days of the effective date, Respondents must establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive Information Security Program protecting the security, confidentiality, and integrity of Covered Information, encompassing documentation, board reporting, designated leadership, risk assessments, safeguards, vendor management, and ongoing evaluation.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Third Party Information Security Assessments for Covered Businesses
provisions.summary: Respondents must obtain initial and biennial independent third-party assessments of the Information Security Program from a qualified Assessor approved by the FTC, covering the first 180 days after the Program is established and each two-year period thereafter for 20 years, with detailed assessment requirements and submission obligations.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Cooperation with Third-Party Information Security Assessor
provisions.summary: Respondents must fully cooperate with the third-party Assessor by providing all relevant information, network and IT asset access, and disclosing all material facts without misrepresentation.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Annual Certification
provisions.summary: Respondents must provide annual certifications from their CEO (or designated senior officer) confirming compliance with the Order, absence of uncorrected material noncompliance, and describing all Covered Incidents affecting 100 or more consumers during the certified period.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Covered Incident Reports
provisions.summary: Within 10 days of notifying any U.S. government entity of a Covered Incident affecting 500 or more consumers, Respondents must submit a report to the Commission detailing the incident's date, facts, affected information types, number of affected consumers, remediation actions taken, and copies of consumer notices.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Acknowledgments of the Order
provisions.summary: Respondents must submit their own acknowledgment of receipt within 10 days, deliver copies of the Order to current and future principals, officers, relevant employees, subsidiaries, and agents for 20 years, and obtain signed acknowledgments from each recipient within 30 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Reports and Notices
provisions.summary: Respondents must submit an initial sworn compliance report one year after issuance, provide sworn notices within 14 days of structural or contact changes or bankruptcy filings, and submit all required documents to the Commission via specified channels.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondents must create certain records for 20 years after the issuance date and retain each for five years (unless otherwise specified), including accounting records, personnel records, consumer complaints, compliance records, System Assessment materials, privacy/security representations, Assessor materials, law enforcement communications, and records of non-compliance.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The Commission is authorized to monitor Respondents' compliance by requesting additional reports, conducting depositions, obtaining records, communicating directly with Respondents, interviewing affiliated individuals, and using all other lawful means including undercover operations.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Modification of Original Decision and Order
provisions.summary: This Decision and Order supersedes the Commission's prior 2010 Decision and Order in In re Rite Aid Corporation, C-4308.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Order Effective Dates
provisions.summary: This Order is final and effective upon publication on ftc.gov and will terminate 20 years from the date of issuance, or 20 years from the most recent date the United States or Commission files a federal court complaint alleging a violation of this Order, whichever is later, with specified exceptions.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Security
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently prohibited from making false or misleading representations about the extent to which they protect the security, privacy, confidentiality, or integrity of personal information collected from consumers.

provisions.title: Comprehensive Information Security Program
provisions.summary: Respondent must establish and maintain a comprehensive written information security program with administrative, technical, and physical safeguards appropriate to its size, complexity, and the sensitivity of the personal information it collects.

provisions.title: Biannual Third-Party Security Assessment

provisions.title: Recordkeeping

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgment and Delivery

provisions.title: Notification of Corporate Changes
provisions.summary: Respondent must notify the FTC at least 30 days prior to any corporate change (dissolution, merger, sale, bankruptcy filing, name/address change, or creation/dissolution of a subsidiary or affiliate) that may affect compliance obligations under this order.

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Respondent must file a written compliance report with the FTC within 60 days of service of the order, and at such other times as the FTC may require, detailing the manner and form in which it has complied.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq

provisions.title: Order Duration and Termination
provisions.summary: The order terminates on December 20, 2022, or twenty years from the most recent date the FTC or United States files a complaint in federal court alleging a violation, whichever is later, with specific exceptions for parts with shorter terms, non-defendant respondents, and complaints filed after termination.

provisions.summary: Respondent must not violate any provision of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act's Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule (Safeguards Rule), 16 C.F.R. Part 314.

provisions.title: Notification of Corporate Changes
provisions.summary: Respondent must notify the FTC at least 30 days before any corporate change that may affect compliance obligations under this order, including dissolution, merger, bankruptcy, or name/address changes; if notice is not possible 30 days in advance, notification must be as soon as practicable.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 314, issued pursuant to Title V of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, 15 U.S.C. § 6801 et seq.

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Respondent must file a written compliance report with the FTC within 180 days of service and at such other times as the FTC may require, including a copy of the initial biennial Assessment.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 314, issued pursuant to Title V of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, 15 U.S.C. § 6801 et seq.

provisions.title: Order Duration and Termination
provisions.summary: The order terminates on December 14, 2025, or twenty years from the most recent date a complaint alleging a violation of the order is filed in federal court, whichever is later, subject to specified exceptions.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 314, issued pursuant to Title V of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, 15 U.S.C. § 6801 et seq.

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Privacy and Security
provisions.summary: Respondents must not misrepresent, in any manner, the extent to which they maintain and protect the privacy, confidentiality, or security of consumers' personal information.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); the Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule (Safeguards Rule), 16 C.F.R. Part 314, issued pursuant to Title V, Subtitle A of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, 15 U.S.C. § 6801-6809; and the Privacy of Consumer Financial Information Rule (Privacy Rule), 16 C.F.R. Part 313, issued pursuant to the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act

provisions.title: Comprehensive Information Security Program
provisions.summary: Respondents must establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive written information security program with administrative, technical, and physical safeguards appropriate to the size, complexity, and sensitivity of personal information handled.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); the Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule (Safeguards Rule), 16 C.F.R. Part 314, issued pursuant to Title V, Subtitle A of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, 15 U.S.C. § 6801-6809; and the Privacy of Consumer Financial Information Rule (Privacy Rule), 16 C.F.R. Part 313, issued pursuant to the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act

provisions.title: Compliance with Safeguards Rule and Privacy Rule
provisions.summary: Respondents must not violate any provision of the FTC Safeguards Rule (16 C.F.R. Part 314) or the Privacy Rule (16 C.F.R. Part 313); compliance with future amendments to those rules will not constitute a violation of this order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); the Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule (Safeguards Rule), 16 C.F.R. Part 314, issued pursuant to Title V, Subtitle A of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, 15 U.S.C. § 6801-6809; and the Privacy of Consumer Financial Information Rule (Privacy Rule), 16 C.F.R. Part 313, issued pursuant to the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act

provisions.title: Third-Party Security Assessments
provisions.summary: Respondents must obtain initial and biennial independent third-party assessments of their information security program covering the first 180 days and each two-year period thereafter for 20 years, with each assessment prepared by a qualified security professional and submitted or retained according to specified timelines.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); the Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule (Safeguards Rule), 16 C.F.R.
